text: today we are tackling America's favorite
food and that is pizza I'm gonna show
you my favorite recipe and the best part
about this recipe is that you get a
crisp crust but with that chewy interior
that everyone's looking for and also you
can make this a day ahead which is super
convenient so how do you start well you
need what most people fear and that is
yeast don't fear yeast it's really easy
to work with once you kind of understand
it a little bit so this is one envelope
of active dry yeast you want to make
sure that you're using active dry yeast
as opposed to instant yeast and what you
need to do is you need to wake it up a
little bit so in front of me I have two
cups of water which is at 110 degrees if
you have one of these little digital
thermometers use that now 110 degrees is
the temperature that kind of wakes up
the yeast you don't want to go over that
because that it might kill the yeast you
know would be too low in temperature
otherwise it won't activate the yeast so
just mix this together and this is gonna
sit for about five minutes until it's
nice and creamy you should start to see
small bubbles appearing and maybe a
frothy film over the top and that way
you know that your yeast is activated
and it will properly rise your pizza
dough if nothing happens your yeast
might have expired it's not alive
anymore so you might have to start over
so before you waste all those
ingredients make sure you go through
this step of waking the yeast up and
making sure it's alive so it's been 5
minutes look at this yeast you guys you
can see how it's bubbled up it's kind of
creamy and texture and it smells like
beer and that's because the fermentation
process is happening now I have a stand
mixer here and to that I'm going to add
3 cups of all-purpose flour now this is
one easy recipe for pizza dough a lot of
people use other types of flours the
Italians will use a double zero flour
which is a much finer flour this recipe
I like it uses all-purpose and I always
have that on hand - the three cups of
flour I'm going to add two teaspoons of
fine sea salt and
I'm going to just turn this on with the
dough hook so that the salt gets
incorporated into the flour now you want
to make sure you go through this step
because once we add the yeast in we
don't want it coming into direct contact
with the salt because salt will actually
kill you you want to disperse it or
break it up with the flour so that it's
spread out of it and it doesn't really
inhibit the process of the fermentation
so that looks mixed enough I'm gonna add
in the water and yeast mixture here and
on low speed with the dough hook I'm
gonna mix this together now it's very
likely you're almost of course going to
have to add more flour
but with baking with bread making when
you're using flour and water or flour
and a liquid a lot depends on the
humidity so if you are in a high
humidity environment you are probably
going to have to add more flour to your
mixture if you are in a low humidity
it's the opposite of battle so once this
mixture comes together you can start
adding more flour so in this bowl here I
have a little over two cups of flour and
you want to add this a little bit at a
time until you get a tacky dough but a
dough not a batter okay so here is about
a half a cup that I'm adding in so you
can see that the dough is pulling away
from the sides you saw it kind of
gathering up on the dough hook it's
still really tacky so I'm going to add a
little bit more flour
okay I'm gonna give this a check again
still kind of tacky and loose and that's
totally fine so what I'm gonna do here
is I'm going to increase the speed now
to about medium and I'm going to need
this on the stand mixer for about ten
minutes so it's been about ten minutes
and now I'm gonna take this off the
stand mixer here and I'm going to finish
kneading by hand so remove the dough
onto a floured surface here
I love these plastic Bowl scrapers
they're really helpful if you're serious
about bread making or pizza making
they make quick work of getting sticky
and tacky dough's out of the bowl much
easier to use than a rubber scraper and
now using well floured hands and you can
even use this bowl scraper to help you
you're going to knead the dough and
kneading is a really simple process of
taking the dough pulling it towards you
or folding it over itself and then
you're gonna push with the heel of your
hand here away from you you can do this
with your bowl scraper it makes really
easy work kind of that folding motion
pushing away from you folding over
pushing away from you and I always
rotate the dough and you're gonna do
this for about five to ten minutes until
the dough is no longer tacky and it's
also extremely smooth I've been kneading
the dough for about ten minutes it's
nice and soft and smooth now we're gonna
start the first proofing of the dough
and to do this just round the dough out
into a ball so now take a large bowl
with a little bit of olive oil here
brush that around the sides and this
goes covered
to a semi warm place nothing too cold
you want the temperature to be around in
between 80 and 90 degrees and now this
will rise for about two hours so it's
been two hours and you can see look at
how it's nice and spongy I'm going to
take this and scrape it out onto a well
floured surface and this is deflating
the dough and that's totally fine
because we're gonna proof this one more
time so well floured hands here and I'm
going to cut this into four equal
portion we'll cut the dough in half and
then we'll cut it in half yet again and
so this recipe actually makes about four
12-inch pizzas it can actually make for
pretty decent sized calzones you could
do a skillet pizza with this and what
I'm gonna do is just shape these into
balls so how do you do that you take the
tacky side which was on the bottom of
the bowl and you take the corners of the
dough you pull it in towards the center
so all four corners come in and then
what I like to do is flip the dough over
get rid of some of the flour on the work
surface here and again it's that same
motion of taking the side of your hands
here and cutting the dough under and
you're really just trying to seal off
the bottom and it creates a nice rounded
shape and now these go onto a floured
rimmed baking sheet and now this goes
into the refrigerator over night so you
can do this in advance and it works out
really well you can freeze it after it
comes out of the refrigerator overnight
put it into individual resealable
plastic bags and all you have to do is
defrost it and you're ready to make a
delicious pizza so there we go
cover with plastic and into the
refrigerator overnight so I have the
dough here that's breast and overnight
the dough here is puffed and beautiful
ready to use now you want to take the
dough maybe use a little bit of flour on
your hands and now is the time to shape
your pizzas now you can do this in one
of two ways you can do it right on the
work surface like this
really what you're doing is you're
pressing the dough out from the center
out to the edges creating I would say a
12 inch circle is great for this size
dough or if you're feeling adventurous
what you can do is you can put the dough
in your hands on top of your knuckles
here and let the weight of the dough
actually pull itself into a nice circle
you can do a mixture of these two things
so once you get the dough into a nice
semi round shape here like this now
you're ready to use it so you can top it
accordingly and this goes right into the
oven now one trick I have here it's my

pizzas is to actually use a piece of

don't have to move the pizza at all
typically in pizzerias they use these
things that's called a pizza peel so you
assemble on the pizza peel here and then
you slide the pizza off into the oven
well this way you're really moving the
parchment itself right on to the pizza
stone so pizza stone as always guys this
goes into your oven before you start
preheating your oven you want to crank

possible that's about 500 degrees and
look at how easy this is this guy's
right onto the pizza stone like that you
don't mess up the shape of your pizza at
